{{short description|American figure skater}} {{for|the country music singer-songwriter| Robin Lee Bruce}} {{Infobox figure skater |name= Robin Lee |image=Robin Lee 1942.jpg |caption=Lee, circa 1942 |fullname= Robin Huntington Lee |country= [[United States]] |birth_date= {{birth date|1919|12|2}} |birth_place= [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] |death_date= {{death date and age|1997|10|8|1919|12|2}} |death_place= [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] |formercoach= |formerchoreographer= |skating club= St. Paul FSC
Chicago FSC
[[SC of New York]]
[[Figure Skating Club of Minneapolis|FSC of Minneapolis]] |retired= |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry| [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[North American Figure Skating Championships|North American Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1939 North American Figure Skating Championships|1939 Toronto]]|[[1939 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1935 North American Figure Skating Championships|1935 Montreal]]|[[1935 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1933 North American Figure Skating Championships|1933 New York]]|[[1933 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} }} '''Robin Huntington Lee''' (December 2, 1919 in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] – October 8, 1997 in [[Minneapolis]]) was an American [[figure skater]]. He was the 1935-1939 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. national champion]]. At age 12, he became the youngest skater to win the junior national title.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/sports/robin-lee-77-figure-skating-champion.html | title = Robin Lee, 77, Figure Skating Champion | work = [[New York Times]] | date = October 14, 1997 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}} At the [[1935 United States Figure Skating Championships]], at the age of 15,{{cite news | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770632,00.html | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20081231075618/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770632,00.html | url-status =dead | archive-date =December 31, 2008 | title = Sport: Figures in Chicago | publisher = [[TIME]] | date = February 22, 1937 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}}{{cite news | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748489-2,00.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091009214225/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748489-2,00.html | url-status = dead | archive-date = October 9, 2009 | title = Sport: Snow & Ice | publisher = [[TIME]] | date = February 18, 1935| accessdate = October 29, 2009}} he became the first and, as of 2008, the only skater to defeat a seven time national champion in the United States. Lee represented the [[United States at the 1936 Winter Olympics]], where he placed 12th. He was selected to compete at the [[1940 Winter Olympics]], which were canceled due to [[World War II]]. During the War, Lee served in the [[U.S. Navy]].{{cite news |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19460422&id=WiQVAAAAIBAJ&pg=7124,4709154 | title = Skating Expert With Ice Cycles Is Ex-Champion | publisher = [[Spokane Daily Chronicle]] | date = April 22, 1946 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}} After the War, Lee skated professionally in ice shows and worked as a coach. Lee was inducted into the [[U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] in 1995. He attended [[Erasmus Hall High School]]. The Robin Lee Midwest Open is a USFS sanctioned competition held each year in the summer by Lee's home club, the [[Figure Skating Club of Minneapolis]], named in his honor.{{cite web|title=Robin Lee Competition|url=http://www.fscmpls.org/robin-lee-competition|website=Figure Skating Club of Minneapolis|accessdate=10 January 2017}} ==Competitive highlights== {| class="wikitable" |- !
